instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Clean board, already had the SMC and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> replaced, I checked for shorts on all power rails from page 100 and all of them are good.

Following the G3 to S3 Power Sequence ALL voltages are correct and present until I get to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> both are pulsing.

When I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I do get a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> but when I do the same <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> don't do nothing and all they do is pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
L7520 and other S3 voltages should pulse too; at same time with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
Didn't note any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Sorry <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and L7520 pulses too.

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was replaced as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message: No pulse on any other big coil???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message: If no pulse at all at L7310/20, check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; pulsing pins 3, 5, 6, 7?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> Pins 3, 5, 6, 7 are pulsing, I replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> just in case but same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
Tried SMC bypass?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses too, SMC bypass same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Then you have the (in)famous 5s pulsing problem?
Check all voltages from page 11; pay atention to series resistors and coils.
